annually to this subject, and we might hope at last the attention of the nation would be aroused. This mOdo commends itself to ladies and matronS who might by this means unobrusively redress the wrongs of suffering humanity. Thousands of.tl1eir sex are condemned to languish Sagh life devoid of hope through the intkmperance of others, and to die a thousand deaths before death relieves them. These evils cannot at once be removed ,but ough. to be prevented by skilful and ju- dicious anticipation. The name of val ued friend might be perpetuated by tie fund, which annual interest appropriated in books or medal by the faculty of col lege to the successful competitor would excite and reward the efforts of genius. Thus would it continue to produce yearly wholesome fruit for the healing of this nation, long after the hands which plant ed it had mouldered in the dust.

 Let the whole moral strength of the nation be arrayed against the evil. Let petition be presented to congress with million of names for an increase of duties on imported spirits, and an excise on SuCH aS are OI uOHtoStiC QtStiIIdI1OH" Let the money thus raised be appropri- ated to promote internal improvement, or education, or some other object as shall be most popular. Let not a mo- ment be lost. Let the Doctors show their skill and prowess in fighting against the monster of intemperance. Let them unite and resist the alarming invasion and expel a common enemy. God and our country demand it. Let teachers and mothers especially show to their ten- der charge, how every step of this re- morseless fend is in crime, and impuri- ty, and cruelty, and blood, till boiling passion shake their little frames, till they are nerved to hold in the conflict the dagger of defence and defiance for this hell engendered tyrant, if he ever dies, must be stabbed by infant hands. Let every patriot and every Christian lend instantly his utmost efforts to- this serv- lice. Let every friendly heart be enga- ged, and every generous arm exerted till, at length, belaboured on all sides

 this Christian ,Abaddon shall be ovcr- thrown and curse. the earth no longer with his existance. PRo PATR1A.

 JEHIEL WILLIAMS, Esq. Jndge. TTPON the Petition of RUFUS FULLER O of Kent, in said district, showing iO this Court that he is the Parent and natural Guar dian Of Linus F. Fuller, Julia Ann Fuller and Rufus Fuller, Jun. all of said Kent, minors. under the age of twenty -one years, that said minors own and possess in fce-sinipIe us ten- ants in common about twenty-thrce acres of land situated in the north part of the town oG Plymouth in Litchfed county, which cana to said minors by descent from their late moth CT Bede Fuller, deceased and their grand mother Mehitable Fem, deceased, and of about the value of seven hundred and fifty dollars--prayng for reasons in said petition set forth that an order might he passed au- thorising and empowering said Petitioner or some other suitable person to sell and convey said premises according to the statute in such case made and provided. As per Petition on file dated May 1st 1897.

 Ordered that said Petition be continued to the 18th day of July 1927, at 12 o'clock at noon, at the Probate Office in New Milford, when and where said Petitioner may be heard on the merits his said Petition. And that notice of the pendency thereof be given by publishing this Order in Newspaper printed at Litchfeld weeks successively at least weeks previous to said 18th day of July 1927.

 Atrue Copy of Record,

 47 Test, NATHANIEL PERRY, Clerk.

SAMUEL PARDEE'S ESTATE. THE Court of Probate for the District of 1 Sharon has allowed and limited six months from this date for the creditors of the estate of

 SAMUEL PARDEE, 7 :. late of Sharon in said district deceased, to present their claims to the subscribers for set tlement.-All claims not thus presented will be debarred recovery.

 ORRIN PARDEE, e r.

 CHAUNCEY PARDEE, N'N'' ''' Sharon, April 80, A. D. tss7. 4S
SAMUEL PARDEE'S ESTATE.

WHEREAS, LAVINA WOODRUFF

 w of Litchfeld, in said County, has brought her petition to this Court against her husband Salmon Woodruff, now residing in parts to her unknown, therein stating, among other things, that the said Salmon, at said Litchfeld, on or about the first day of July 1893, wilfully deserted her, and ever since has continued, and still continues, his desertion, residing out of this state, in the total neglect of all the duties of the marriage covenant, on his part, to he performed, and praying for bill of divorce from the said Salmon, as her petition on file, dated the 9th day of Februa- ry 1827s ......,-. ... ~

 Ordered by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchfeld, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next --and that the pendency of said petition, and copy ofthis order, be published six weeks suceessively, according to the statute in such case provided. in paper printed in Litchfeld, called the LitchfeId County Post, and in a pa per printed in New-Haven, called the Colum- Lian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court,

 ->s. F. WOLCOTT, Clerk.

pfeVentlOn. AS tHis iS INe mOSt VsO"1ANa oa all diseases which infest the country, the humanely generOns proprietor of the American Medical Recorder, will pardon the intimation of theme for one of his annual prize essays. Vaccination demonstrates that the prevention as we'll as the cure of diseases belongs not inap- propriately the medical art. ...s

 A distinguished physician has mentioned the use of tobacco as one cause Of intem- perance, since it vitates the taste and ren- ders the most natural, simple and whole some drinks unpaltable. Parents should therefore seasonably and earnestly dis- suade their children from an unnecessary use of it. The prepossesslons and an- tipatIlies of children are easily formed and rendered durable. Mothers especially should be reminded of the vast importance of instilling into the minds of their tender offspring love of natural simplicity and temperance should teach them to abhor and resist firmly yet courteously the noxious superAuities which fashion prescribes, should inspire them with perpetual jealousy of the first approaches of iHtemperance, should disclose to them the afluring insiduousness of its beginnings, only to bite at last like a serpent and sting like an adder, should fill them with dread of tippling houses, those suburbs. of hell, and should stamp their re- tentjve memories with views as awful, if possible ,as reality of the tremendous conse- quences of yielding in the least to this pow erty-creating, healtIl-ruining, soul-damning sin. But after all that can ba done by the friends of temperance to excite parents to perform this duty to their ofisprings, many will neglect it. To remedy, in some de- gree, this neglect, teachers of common and other schools should be encouraged to ad- dress the children and youth, whose nor als and manners are committed to their care, on. this awfally interesting theme to hold up for their imitation the temper ance of the father of his country, and the shining examples of eminently good men of past ages,and Illustrate with affectionate

 earnestness at least every week inc advan- tages of sobricty, and the wretchedness of intemperance. And it seems not unwor- thy of legislative dignity to dictate a fa- miliar and pertinent address to the rising hope of the community relative to this mo- mentuous subject, a subject in which their welfare and that of the state are a. like deeply involved, and require instruc- ters either to place it in their hands, or to read it to them statedly. For our youth are caught by the monster of intemper- { ante in vast numbers like fishes in net, not dreaming that danger is nigh till they are unable to escape. ---..

 Agricultural societies might promote the

 object by proposing premiums for farms

 which are cultivated without the use of ar-

 dent spirits. As drunkenness does not

 exist where the vine fourishes, its cultiva-

 ton is especially worthy of their attention

 and thatof other patriotic associations and

 individuals. Our climate and soil are SC

 various that the culture of it would at least

 in some sections, be attended with highly probable success. It may be well to re-

 fleet that only a few years since, eight bags of cotton, which article now constitutes the

 chief staple of our country, were seized ig

 Liverpool as product not of American 1 growth. The currant thrives and bears we'll in most parts of the Republic, and as the wines an auxiliary oftemperance, and in general good substitute for ardent spir- its, it ought be more cultivated. Fruits of every kind ought 10 be cultivated, because they are friendly to temperance, and tend to cherish a natural taste perhaps as pow erfully as the poisonous plant before men, toned tends to prevent it. The love of fruit is not generally united with thirst for ardent spirits

 Agreater number, and far greater vari- esy Ofracts on this subject ought to be put IntO circulation. They should be ad pic ed and addressed to every class of the com mUairy, especially to its younger mem- berS- The English to resist the invasion of the Spanish armada dispersed plates and pictures of the instruments of torture which were said to have been on board of it. History informs us of a people, who occasionally took their children to see slave in a state of intoxication, that they might imbibe strong aversion to it from so odious sight. Tract societies might publish representations of the effect of ardent spirits, annexing brief notices in prose and poetry descriptive, perceptive, or satirical. These if rightly conducted might induce just and inextinguishable antipathy in the minds of thousands of children against an improper use of intox- icating liquors.

 The prevention of intemperance is a

commence an the l6th oI Way next. Tuition, per quarter of 19 weeks, 6 dollars. Music, |" ''' 12 French, q Y" 5

 Drawing, :" Y" 8

 Scholars in the lower branches are charged $1O ADr the term of twenty -four weeks. The text books used are Murray's Grammar,-W oodbridge's Geog- raphy and Atlas,-Dabofs or Willetts Arith- metic,-Abridgement of Blair's Rhetoric.- Conversations on Natural Philosophy,-do. on Chemistry, Moral Philosophy Hedges Logic,-Al;son on Taste,-Abridge- ment of Universal History.-Russelps Mod ern Europe, with Coote's Confirmation, and Goodrich's American History. The Latin & Greek languages, the Mathematical sciences, with any other studies, can be pursued at the option of the scholar.

 The Instructors hope that the long estab- lished reputation of this Institution; their ex- perience and attention to their duties; the beauty and healtfuness of the village of Litchfeld; and polished manners and litera- ry character of its inhabitants, may author ise them to request the continuance of the public patronage.

 Board can be obtained from St, to S2,0O per week. exclusive of washing.

 Litchfeld, April A, 1927.

 COacINded.

 But you are told my countrymen that the press is the ,palIadium of your liber- ties, that the press will save you. The assumption is gratuitous. Where did the oress ever save nation The press, like every thing else in this country speaks the mind of the people, and is under their control. It has no power but such as the people give it. Its agency depends on their volition. How then can it reform nation unwilling to be reformed How can it give sobriety to the most intemper- ate people that ever existed How much longer. how much more must it increase before the press begins to, exert its re- straining energy How much lower must we descend in the scale of national degra- dationebefore we feel its elevating power If the press had not hitherto exerted with effect its controlling agency, what pledge ? can it give that it will hereafter do it /? If this engine was intellectual at first to pre- vent or repair the breach, how can it re- store the foundations which as the current of intemperance- grows stronger are every year more and more swept away ? The press has not been adequate to the control, much less will it be to the extirpation of the evil. If it does not stay us in our downward course, what rational hope does it afford of efficiency to recoverthis nation from its degenerate condition to its pris- tine temperance ,and the presentinhabitants, or their prosterity, to the health, corporial vigor, and longevity, oftheir forefathers !! The press reveals the past not the future. 1t makes no promises. Much less c0n it promise to protect and preserve nation increasingly incorporate. If this nation so continues, and yet preserves it's liberties and its privileges, it will be an anomaly in history. Such an event is in opposition to all past experience. But ifsthe press be in truth friendly to- the perpetuity of our institutions, and really hostile to this iniquitious pestilence which vastly more endangers them than Africo-American bay. onets,or than all the cannon of Europe,- fit be really willing to sound the alarm that shall ring through nations ears, let that tfriendship be evinced. Tell the great Emporium which expends, if her own statement be true $5 ,OOO daily to purchase wretchedness and pollution, and pow erty and crime, I--tell every Ameri- can from the Lake to the Gulf, from Bos- ton to the Missouri that persevcring in our present habits we shall be ruined ,-tha elegance in literature, and refinement ir the arts, did not save Greece, that ths wealth of the world could not save Rome, ,TH and that a happy form of gov. ernment will not save us without temper. ance demonstrate the absudity of apply ing, for defence against the militant ex tremcs of heat and cold to this Proteal god under whose supplying influence som, are every year leftsto be stiffned in fros or immolated in flames. Repeat till i cannot be forgotten what Plutarch ha. said, ''of all the destroyer of nerves healtt and life this is the greatest" and I have g no doubt but it has broken down more constitutions, brought on more distempers and sent more people tO an early grave than all other vices of the world united and the memorable words of late sage, s'all the crimes on earth do not destroy so many of the HUMAN RACE, nor alieneate so much PROPERTY as drunkenness''*** Ex- pose the folly of building continually aims houses, poor--houses, hospitals, asylum refnges, bTidewells, treadmllls, prisons and pe1itenfisries, and of educating the rising generation to i'll them of laylshing mill- 5ous for the sws q tAs srsl. and of doing aaGaiug tn rgmave Gkr GaaEsg-

 LaE gs'aESamsn sf tze sar rsEeat wath the vuiEa Gf uiERadsu. wiazEr has been SGrs1 said tliGn & ulir,,ss-fs1ntis ef all the criases cos- mifrs,f ars through uhs mflIeucs of spiriIt- anuH EIglnrs,' ' S4 tms-rhrds of those now pHlperss ars made ss sy Eareuspersncs. '' And leu nat rfe ~ ssScyg faaEes aayIT pFe- Veur the execution of that summary jus tsce upon this flint hearted InstIgztor to criminal deeds which an injured country demands Drag out this overgrown giant, and huEl at him the stones of exfermIna- ton. The evils he has done this country deserve not any redress but vengance. Let those guilty of Drunkenness undergo civ- il disabilities like that in Spain, where for merly man convicted of drunkenness was legally incapacitated to give testimony in a court of justice. Let every means be de- vised to pour contempt on intemperance, and let the bodies off the suicidal wretches, who persevsre, be delivered over for dis- section. Thus might the innocent sleep m safety, which never can be the case, till
EesAY ON INTEMPERANCE,

annually to this subject, and we might hope at last the attention of the nation would be aroused. This mOdo commends itself to ladies and matronS who might by this means unobrusively redress the wrongs of suffering humanity. Thousands of.tl1eir sex are condemned to languish Sagh life devoid of hope through the intkmperance of others, and to die a thousand deaths before death relieves them. These evils cannot at once be removed ,but ough. to be prevented by skilful and ju- dicious anticipation. The name of val ued friend might be perpetuated by tie fund, which annual interest appropriated in books or medal by the faculty of col lege to the successful competitor would excite and reward the efforts of genius. Thus would it continue to produce yearly wholesome fruit for the healing of this nation, long after the hands which plant ed it had mouldered in the dust.

 Let the whole moral strength of the nation be arrayed against the evil. Let petition be presented to congress with million of names for an increase of duties on imported spirits, and an excise on SuCH aS are OI uOHtoStiC QtStiIIdI1OH" Let the money thus raised be appropri- ated to promote internal improvement, or education, or some other object as shall be most popular. Let not a mo- ment be lost. Let the Doctors show their skill and prowess in fighting against the monster of intemperance. Let them unite and resist the alarming invasion and expel a common enemy. God and our country demand it. Let teachers and mothers especially show to their ten- der charge, how every step of this re- morseless fend is in crime, and impuri- ty, and cruelty, and blood, till boiling passion shake their little frames, till they are nerved to hold in the conflict the dagger of defence and defiance for this hell engendered tyrant, if he ever dies, must be stabbed by infant hands. Let every patriot and every Christian lend instantly his utmost efforts to- this serv- lice. Let every friendly heart be enga- ged, and every generous arm exerted till, at length, belaboured on all sides

 this Christian ,Abaddon shall be ovcr- thrown and curse. the earth no longer with his existance. PRo PATR1A.

pfeVentlOn. AS tHis iS INe mOSt VsO"1ANa oa all diseases which infest the country, the humanely generOns proprietor of the American Medical Recorder, will pardon the intimation of theme for one of his annual prize essays. Vaccination demonstrates that the prevention as we'll as the cure of diseases belongs not inap- propriately the medical art. ...s

 A distinguished physician has mentioned the use of tobacco as one cause Of intem- perance, since it vitates the taste and ren- ders the most natural, simple and whole some drinks unpaltable. Parents should therefore seasonably and earnestly dis- suade their children from an unnecessary use of it. The prepossesslons and an- tipatIlies of children are easily formed and rendered durable. Mothers especially should be reminded of the vast importance of instilling into the minds of their tender offspring love of natural simplicity and temperance should teach them to abhor and resist firmly yet courteously the noxious superAuities which fashion prescribes, should inspire them with perpetual jealousy of the first approaches of iHtemperance, should disclose to them the afluring insiduousness of its beginnings, only to bite at last like a serpent and sting like an adder, should fill them with dread of tippling houses, those suburbs. of hell, and should stamp their re- tentjve memories with views as awful, if possible ,as reality of the tremendous conse- quences of yielding in the least to this pow erty-creating, healtIl-ruining, soul-damning sin. But after all that can ba done by the friends of temperance to excite parents to perform this duty to their ofisprings, many will neglect it. To remedy, in some de- gree, this neglect, teachers of common and other schools should be encouraged to ad- dress the children and youth, whose nor als and manners are committed to their care, on. this awfally interesting theme to hold up for their imitation the temper ance of the father of his country, and the shining examples of eminently good men of past ages,and Illustrate with affectionate

 earnestness at least every week inc advan- tages of sobricty, and the wretchedness of intemperance. And it seems not unwor- thy of legislative dignity to dictate a fa- miliar and pertinent address to the rising hope of the community relative to this mo- mentuous subject, a subject in which their welfare and that of the state are a. like deeply involved, and require instruc- ters either to place it in their hands, or to read it to them statedly. For our youth are caught by the monster of intemper- { ante in vast numbers like fishes in net, not dreaming that danger is nigh till they are unable to escape. ---..

 Agricultural societies might promote the

 object by proposing premiums for farms

 which are cultivated without the use of ar-

 dent spirits. As drunkenness does not

 exist where the vine fourishes, its cultiva-

 ton is especially worthy of their attention

 and thatof other patriotic associations and

 individuals. Our climate and soil are SC

 various that the culture of it would at least

 in some sections, be attended with highly probable success. It may be well to re-

 fleet that only a few years since, eight bags of cotton, which article now constitutes the

 chief staple of our country, were seized ig

 Liverpool as product not of American 1 growth. The currant thrives and bears we'll in most parts of the Republic, and as the wines an auxiliary oftemperance, and in general good substitute for ardent spir- its, it ought be more cultivated. Fruits of every kind ought 10 be cultivated, because they are friendly to temperance, and tend to cherish a natural taste perhaps as pow erfully as the poisonous plant before men, toned tends to prevent it. The love of fruit is not generally united with thirst for ardent spirits

 Agreater number, and far greater vari- esy Ofracts on this subject ought to be put IntO circulation. They should be ad pic ed and addressed to every class of the com mUairy, especially to its younger mem- berS- The English to resist the invasion of the Spanish armada dispersed plates and pictures of the instruments of torture which were said to have been on board of it. History informs us of a people, who occasionally took their children to see slave in a state of intoxication, that they might imbibe strong aversion to it from so odious sight. Tract societies might publish representations of the effect of ardent spirits, annexing brief notices in prose and poetry descriptive, perceptive, or satirical. These if rightly conducted might induce just and inextinguishable antipathy in the minds of thousands of children against an improper use of intox- icating liquors.

 The prevention of intemperance is a

commence an the l6th oI Way next. Tuition, per quarter of 19 weeks, 6 dollars. Music, |" ''' 12 French, q Y" 5

 Drawing, :" Y" 8

 Scholars in the lower branches are charged $1O ADr the term of twenty -four weeks. The text books used are Murray's Grammar,-W oodbridge's Geog- raphy and Atlas,-Dabofs or Willetts Arith- metic,-Abridgement of Blair's Rhetoric.- Conversations on Natural Philosophy,-do. on Chemistry, Moral Philosophy Hedges Logic,-Al;son on Taste,-Abridge- ment of Universal History.-Russelps Mod ern Europe, with Coote's Confirmation, and Goodrich's American History. The Latin & Greek languages, the Mathematical sciences, with any other studies, can be pursued at the option of the scholar.

 The Instructors hope that the long estab- lished reputation of this Institution; their ex- perience and attention to their duties; the beauty and healtfuness of the village of Litchfeld; and polished manners and litera- ry character of its inhabitants, may author ise them to request the continuance of the public patronage.

 Board can be obtained from St, to S2,0O per week. exclusive of washing.

 Litchfeld, April A, 1927.

full articles.article:
CoIlere, last uastsuan, sSrittenIy Mr. JUDAH

 ELY of Bu6alO county ". ".

 COacINded.

 But you are told my countrymen that the press is the ,palIadium of your liber- ties, that the press will save you. The assumption is gratuitous. Where did the oress ever save nation The press, like every thing else in this country speaks the mind of the people, and is under their control. It has no power but such as the people give it. Its agency depends on their volition. How then can it reform nation unwilling to be reformed How can it give sobriety to the most intemper- ate people that ever existed How much longer. how much more must it increase before the press begins to, exert its re- straining energy How much lower must we descend in the scale of national degra- dationebefore we feel its elevating power If the press had not hitherto exerted with effect its controlling agency, what pledge ? can it give that it will hereafter do it /? If this engine was intellectual at first to pre- vent or repair the breach, how can it re- store the foundations which as the current of intemperance- grows stronger are every year more and more swept away ? The press has not been adequate to the control, much less will it be to the extirpation of the evil. If it does not stay us in our downward course, what rational hope does it afford of efficiency to recoverthis nation from its degenerate condition to its pris- tine temperance ,and the presentinhabitants, or their prosterity, to the health, corporial vigor, and longevity, oftheir forefathers !! The press reveals the past not the future. 1t makes no promises. Much less c0n it promise to protect and preserve nation increasingly incorporate. If this nation so continues, and yet preserves it's liberties and its privileges, it will be an anomaly in history. Such an event is in opposition to all past experience. But ifsthe press be in truth friendly to- the perpetuity of our institutions, and really hostile to this iniquitious pestilence which vastly more endangers them than Africo-American bay. onets,or than all the cannon of Europe,- fit be really willing to sound the alarm that shall ring through nations ears, let that tfriendship be evinced. Tell the great Emporium which expends, if her own statement be true $5 ,OOO daily to purchase wretchedness and pollution, and pow erty and crime, I--tell every Ameri- can from the Lake to the Gulf, from Bos- ton to the Missouri that persevcring in our present habits we shall be ruined ,-tha elegance in literature, and refinement ir the arts, did not save Greece, that ths wealth of the world could not save Rome, ,TH and that a happy form of gov. ernment will not save us without temper. ance demonstrate the absudity of apply ing, for defence against the militant ex tremcs of heat and cold to this Proteal god under whose supplying influence som, are every year leftsto be stiffned in fros or immolated in flames. Repeat till i cannot be forgotten what Plutarch ha. said, ''of all the destroyer of nerves healtt and life this is the greatest" and I have g no doubt but it has broken down more constitutions, brought on more distempers and sent more people tO an early grave than all other vices of the world united and the memorable words of late sage, s'all the crimes on earth do not destroy so many of the HUMAN RACE, nor alieneate so much PROPERTY as drunkenness''*** Ex- pose the folly of building continually aims houses, poor--houses, hospitals, asylum refnges, bTidewells, treadmllls, prisons and pe1itenfisries, and of educating the rising generation to i'll them of laylshing mill- 5ous for the sws q tAs srsl. and of doing aaGaiug tn rgmave Gkr GaaEsg-

 LaE gs'aESamsn sf tze sar rsEeat wath the vuiEa Gf uiERadsu. wiazEr has been SGrs1 said tliGn & ulir,,ss-fs1ntis ef all the criases cos- mifrs,f ars through uhs mflIeucs of spiriIt- anuH EIglnrs,' ' S4 tms-rhrds of those now pHlperss ars made ss sy Eareuspersncs. '' And leu nat rfe ~ ssScyg faaEes aayIT pFe- Veur the execution of that summary jus tsce upon this flint hearted InstIgztor to criminal deeds which an injured country demands Drag out this overgrown giant, and huEl at him the stones of exfermIna- ton. The evils he has done this country deserve not any redress but vengance. Let those guilty of Drunkenness undergo civ- il disabilities like that in Spain, where for merly man convicted of drunkenness was legally incapacitated to give testimony in a court of justice. Let every means be de- vised to pour contempt on intemperance, and let the bodies off the suicidal wretches, who persevsre, be delivered over for dis- section. Thus might the innocent sleep m safety, which never can be the case, till
